name: QUEEN'S GAMBIT
idea: The 'gambit' is a false sacrifice: if Black takes 2...dxc4, White easily recovers the pawn with e3 then Bxc4. The idea is to attack Black's center with c4. If Black defends with ...e6 (Declined), their Bc8 remains locked in. If ...c6 (Slav), they keep the possibility of bringing out the Bishop. This is the quintessential strategic opening, played at the highest level for over a century.
errors_white: Playing e4 too early without preparation: the center collapses if Black is well developed
Premature cxd5: frees Black and gives them easy play with ...exd5 or ...cxd5
Neglecting the Nb1: this Knight must go to c3 to support e4 and control d5
errors_black: Keeping the c4 pawn after ...dxc4: costs too much time and White recovers with advantage
...Bf5 before ...e6 in the Declined: the Bishop can be attacked by Qb3 or cxd5 followed by Qb3
...c5 without preparation: opens the position when Black is behind in development
development: Nf3 and Nc3 are the natural moves - control e5 and d5 respectively
Bf4 (London System), Bg5 (pins Nf6) or e3 then Bd3 depending on the variation
After e3, develop to d3 (controls e4) or take on c4 if ...dxc4
Classical kingside castle after e3 and Bd3/Be2
Stay flexible - avoid premature sorties, often c2 for the c-file
Rc1 for the semi-open c-file, Rd1 to support d4

traps.name: Elephant Trap
traps.desc: 2...e5?? 3.dxe5 d4 (hoping to recover) 4.e3! dxe3 5.Qxd8+ Kxd8 6.fxe3 and White has an extra pawn in the endgame. AVOID (Black): Never play ...e5 on move 2! It's a blunder.

traps.name: Accepted Trap
traps.desc: After 2...dxc4 3.Nf3 b5?? (wanting to keep the pawn) 4.a4! a6 5.axb5 axb5 6.Rxa8 and White wins the Rook! AVOID (Black): Don't play ...b5 - return the pawn with ...e6 and ...c5.

traps.name: Cambridge Springs
traps.desc: 5...Nbd7 6.Bg5 Qa5! pins the Nc3 and threatens ...Ne4 or ...Bb4. The Bg5 is attacked by ...h6 and ...Ne4. AVOID (White): Play Nd2 instead of Nf3, or Bd2 to defend c3.

variants.name: Queen's Gambit Declined
variants.uci: d2d4 d7d5 c2c4 e7e6 b1c3 g8f6 c1g5 f8e7 e2e3
variants.white_plan: The Bg5 pins the Nf6 defending d5. After Nf3, Bd3, 0-0, the pressure on d5 is enormous. Aim for cxd5 exd5 to create an isolated pawn.
variants.black_plan: Defend solidly with ...0-0, ...Nbd7, ...c6. Seek to free the Bc8 with ...dxc4 then ...b6/...Bb7 or ...e5.

variants.name: Queen's Gambit Accepted
variants.uci: d2d4 d7d5 c2c4 d5c4 g1f3 g8f6 e2e3 e7e6 f1c4
variants.white_plan: Recover the pawn and develop quickly. After 0-0 and Qe2, prepare e4 for an ideal center.
variants.black_plan: Return the pawn gracefully and play ...c5 to attack the center. Rapid development with ...Be7, ...0-0, ...a6/...b5.

variants.name: Slav Defense
variants.uci: d2d4 d7d5 c2c4 c7c6 g1f3 g8f6 b1c3 d5c4
variants.white_plan: Recover the pawn with a4 and e4. The structure is open and White has more space but Black is solid.
variants.black_plan: Bring out the Bishop BEFORE ...e6! Play ...Bf5 (classical Slav) then ...e6. The Bishop is active unlike in the Declined.
